title: Silver King (baseball)
text:
Silver King (January 11, 1868 – May 21, 1938), born Charles Frederick Koenig in <a href="St.%20Louis">St. Louis</a>, Missouri, was a <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> player from 1886 through 1897.
In a 10-year career, spent primarily as a <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a>, King played for the <a href="Kansas%20City%20Cowboys%20%28National%20League%29">Kansas City Cowboys</a> (1886), <a href="St.%20Louis%20Browns%20%28NL%29">St. Louis Browns</a> (1887–89), <a href="Chicago%20Pirates">Chicago Pirates</a> (1890), <a href="Pittsburgh%20Pirates">Pittsburgh Pirates</a> (1891), <a href="New%20York%20Giants%20%28NL%29">New York Giants</a> (1892–93), <a href="Cincinnati%20Reds">Cincinnati Reds</a> (1893), and <a href="Washington%20Senators%20%281891%E2%80%9399%29">Washington Senators</a> (1896–97). The first part of King's nickname was a reference to the color of his hair, while the latter part was a translation of his German <a href="surname">surname</a>.
King was an unusual pitcher for his time. Gripping the ball with unusually large hands, he delivered the ball without a <a href="Pitching%20position">windup</a>. He was also one of the first pitchers in major league history to employ a <a href="Submarine%20%28baseball%29">sidearm</a> delivery. The unconventional methods worked, as he went on to pitch 3,190 <a href="innings%20pitched">innings</a>, winning 203 games with 1229 <a href="strikeout">strikeout</a>s and a 3.18 <a href="earned%20run%20average">earned run average</a> in 397 <a href="games%20pitched">games</a>. His strong <a href="fastball">fastball</a> enabled him to become a notable strikeout artist; he finished among the league's top 10 in that category six times.
King's best season came in 1888, when he led the Browns to their fourth consecutive <a href="American%20Association%20%2819th%20century%29">American Association</a> championship. That year, King led the league with 585 innings pitched in 66 games, 45 wins, and a 1.64 ERA. In 1890, he jumped to Chicago of the <a href="Players%27%20League">Players' League</a> and added another ERA title while winning 30 games. On June 21, 1890, King threw a <a href="no-hitter">no-hitter</a> for Chicago, the only one in the league's one-year history. (King lost 1–0, and pitched only <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20080526075129/http%3A//www.baseballlibrary.com/chronology/byyear.php%3Fyear%3D1890">eight innings</a> in the loss, so this game is not officially recognized by MLB as a no-hitter.)
After baseball, King returned to his native St. Louis. He died in 1938, at age 70, and was buried at New St. Marcus Cemetery in St. Louis.
